## Dune as Environmental Literature

Frank Herbert's 1965 novel Dune is widely considered one of the best sci-fi books ever written and one of the first to take environmental concerns seriously.(no content)Dune has been called the "first planetary ecology novel on a grand scale" and Herbert hoped it would be seen as an "environmental awareness handbook"(no content)Some scholars have argued that Dune is one of the earliest examples of climate fiction and today, it is considered one of the first works of what critics call climate fiction, or cli-fi.

## Herbert's Ecological Inspiration

Herbert's environmental focus originated from a real-world ecological project. In 1957, Herbert visited Florence, Oregon, where the U.S. Department of Agriculture was attempting to stabilize the area's sand dunes by planting European beachgrass and other fast-growing foliage.(no content)Herbert planned to write a journalism article on Oregon's dunes, titled "They Stopped the Moving Sands," which prompted Herbert to begin researching dunes, deserts and ecology as a whole. The author later claimed to have read over 200 books as background for Dune.

## Environmental Movement Connection

Herbert's novel became a touchstone for the burgeoning environmental movement of the late 1960s and 70s.(no content)After Dune was published in 1965, the environmental movement eagerly embraced it. Herbert spoke at Philadelphia's first Earth Day in 1970, and in the first edition of the Whole Earth Catalog, Dune was advertised with the tagline: "The metaphor is ecology. The theme revolution."

## Ecological Themes and Allegory

The text is rife with allegory, inviting readers to draw parallels to the real-world environmental issues. Critics view spice as an analogy for oil and the oil trade.(no content)In The Dune Encyclopedia, writer Willis E. McNelly points out that the Dune series can "be construed as a thinly veiled allegory of our world's insatiable appetite for oil and other petroleum products."(no content)Herbert's decision to examine the messianic superhero against a backdrop of ecological concerns was no accident. Herbert explained: "I had already written several pieces about ecological matters, but my superhero concept filled me with a concern that ecology might be the next banner for demagogues...I could begin to see the shape of a global problem, no part of it separated from any other—social ecology, political ecology, economic ecology."

## Contemporary Relevance to Climate Change

Paul Atreides' fate — and that of the intergalactic empire — is inextricably linked to the climate and ecology of the desert planet Arrakis. Frank Herbert designed his beloved story, "Dune," that way intentionally, as a critique of our own world and a cautionary tale for the future.(no content)Make no mistake, Earth's changing climate means we'll be forced to find and conserve water in different ways as well. The novel's focus on water scarcity and desert survival resonates strongly with contemporary climate concerns.

## Herbert's Environmental Legacy

In 1970, on the First Earth Day, Frank Herbert spoke to 30,000 people in Philadelphia and he told them, 'I don't want to be in the position of telling my grandchildren, 'I'm sorry, there's no more Earth left for you. We've used it all up.'"(no content)Dune also paved the way for other speculative fiction authors offering similar warnings. Think Margaret Atwood and Seattle's own Octavia Butler.

The novel remains a powerful example of how science fiction can engage with pressing environmental issues while entertaining readers, making it particularly relevant for youth activists and climate advocates today.
